title: Wednesday, 12th June 2019
bodyHTML:
11:08 am
JP11:08am

Morning all.

VV75 morning
SupposeToBeWorking... Morning all.
JP11:08am

This is Markets Live, FT Alphaville's daily royal rumble.

Markkus morning
JP11:09am

Bryce is away for the rest of the week, so unfortunately you're stuck with me. And my incompetence.

AMALtd morning
11:09 am
JP11:09am

Speaking of incompetence...

SupposeToBeWorking... Happy Boris-Johnson-leadership-campaign-start-day.
Patience Good morning.
JP11:10am

Happy Boris Johnson day!

JP11:10am

Boris Johnson’s promise to take Britain out of the EU with or without a deal on the scheduled Brexit date of October 31 has been undermined by a confidential cabinet note warning that the country is still far from prepared for the disruption of a disorderly exit.

The note, seen by the Financial Times, says the government needs six to eight months of engagement with the pharmaceutical industry “to ensure adequate arrangements are in place to build stockpiles of medicines by October 31”.

It also says that it would take “at least 4-5 months” to improve trader readiness for the new border checks that might be required, including the provision of financial incentives to encourage exporters and importers to register for new schemes.

11:11 am
JP11:11am

That's from a new story by George Parker: https://www.ft.com...-a24d-b42f641eca37

red waiting for another muppet to bid for intu so deck is cleared to short again

The upshot is from the press release, not much has changed. But the shares are off quite a bit.

JP11:19am

Tobacco sales are slowing, but vaping and other ways to soil your body are growing.

Excel Developer #BoJo #Brexit: professionals tend to be pro-EU but also better paid. Interesting to see if BoJo's tax cut for professionals is enough to bribe their support.
Markkus Cigarette sales declining - who knew? And yet full-year guidance confirmed...
JP11:20am

Here's Citi:

11:19 am
JP11:20am

Full-year outlook unchanged; 1H detail a little weak — As usual, BAT’s 1H trading statement put more emphasis on the year than the half, stating it remains on track to fulfill its previous full-year guidance: OSG in the mid- to upper-half of the 3-5% range; New Category growth of 30-50%; and constant currency EPS of high single digits. The comments on the 1H performance around NGPs and share were a little disappointing, in our view. BAT also cut guidance for the U.S., but that is not at all surprising.

JP11:20am

NGP growth has started slowly but is expected to build — BAT posted NGP sales of £883 mln in 2018. That figure was below our hopes, but it now turns out it was boosted by pipeline filling, a point not made at the time. BAT says that as a result, 1H19 NGP sales growth will be below the 30-50% target. However, sales should accelerate in 2H due to “a sharper focus” on the main markets, and new product launches in Japan, including an induction heated version of glo, called “glo Pro”, and a much smaller device, called “glo Nano”.

JP11:20am

New products test well against competitors — In its presentation, BAT said its NGPs line up well against its competitors. In heated tobacco, BAT says glo Pro gives satisfaction scores at parity with iQos in consumer tests. In e-vapor, BAT says ePen3 has retained a higher market share in the UK than Juul. In modern oral, BAT says its share is accelerating in Europe, and that in the U.S. it plans to make Velo available in about 70,000 stores by year end. (Swedish Match says Zyn will be in 60,000, although we expect a bit more.)

SupposeToBeWorking... @Excel Developer Isn't the tax cut mainly aimed at high income pensioners. That's quite a different demographic...
Fh @Excel, what good is a tax cut if you've been made redundant as your job moves to Frankfurt?
11:20 am
JP11:21am

In cigarettes, BAT is focusing more on value share than volume — For a long time, BAT has trumpeted the growth of volume share globally, which typically rose 40bps a year. In 1H19, however, volume share fell 10bps while value share rose 10bps. Both BAT and Imperial are emphasizing value more than volume at the moment, which helps explain why the pricing environment is strong currently. We are, however, surprised by the extent of the slowdown at BAT.

Excel Developer @SupposeToBeWorking... : pensioners on between £50000 and £80000? how many are their of those?
JP11:21am

BAT has sensibly lowered U.S. volume guidance — In Jan-June ‘19, industry shipments fell 5.3%, worse than historically but much less bad than the Nielsen figures. BAT now forecasts -4% to -5% for the industry for 2019, which seems realistic to us as we’re at -5%.
Share price reaction seems overdone — In mid-morning, BAT shares were down 4%, admittedly after a 11% rally since the end of May. As we’ve said, we think the statement was a little weak, but -4% seems excessive to us. We think some of the comments about the outlook were quite bullish, but the market clearly is only interested in hard results, not projections and assertions about how well NGPs do in focus groups. We continue to believe the results will improve in 2H, so retain our 12-month Buy recommendation.

Excel Developer *there*
Excel Developer @Fh : number of city job lost much smaller than predicted.
JP11:21am

So buy the rumour, sell the news.

11:21 am
JP11:22am

What's new in markets eh?

cracklenpop @Excel DeveloperThe electorate Johnson is appealing to is MPs and 160,000 Conservative party members, not ''professionals'.
JP11:22am

Here's Jefferies:

JP11:22am

Tobacco delivery is solid overall, with good pricing and margin development, and the company confident of hitting HSD ex-FX EPS growth this year. With FX also supportive we could expect 1-2% consensus upgrades. Likely to weigh though is the update around RRP (1H guided sales disappointing and Glo market share in Japan stalling), while the fact cigarette share is down for the first time in years could also worry. Focus now will be on BAT presentation at a conference in Paris this morning, expected 0745 London time, where no doubt questions will be centred around these two areas.

11:22 am
JP11:22am

To Like

1) Update around overall group growth encouraging: On sales for the year, they look to grow ex-FX in the mid‐upper half of 3‐5% (we are at 5.3%). On EBIT they look to grow in the upper half of 5‐7% (we are at 7.1%). They say good adjusted operating margin improvement expected. For FX they now see support of 1% on EPS for the year (vs headwind previously). The company remains confident of delivering HSD ex-FX EPS growth for the year (we are at 8%). With consensus currently looking for reported EPS growth of 5.9% for the year, even assuming up to date with FX, we would expect upgrades of at least 1-2% on the back of this.

Excel Developer @cracklenpop : of whom the median income is $40,000
Excel Developer * £40000 *
SupposeToBeWorking... @Excel The reason is that they don't pay NI, only income tax. Johnson also planned to increase NI. Quite a few on DB pensions (these days doctors and civil servants, but in the past there were lots of generous DB schemes)
JP11:23am

Not to Like

1) Have lost cigarette market share YTD: One of the core BAT strengths has been continued share gains for the last several years. The fact that cigarette volume share is down 10bps YTD is, therefore, likely to cause some concern.

2) RRP delivery and guidance disappointing: Of particular concern will likely be the 1H19 guided number, the company suggesting RRP sales could come in around £520mn (approaching growth of 30%). This is little acceleration vs 2H18 when the reported number was £479. It also comes in below our estimate of £675. The company flags the US as the headwind, reflecting the unwinding of high year-end 2018 trade inventories following the restocking of Vibe and low first quarter trade demand due to regulatory uncertainty in the US. While we know this dynamic in the US is true, and Alto market share trends are encouraging (offtake ml share at 8.3% YTD compared to 6.9% in February), what is more likely to worry, given how accretive it is to sales, is Glo market share in Japan. This was at 5% YTD and compares to 5.1% in February, suggesting share trends have stalled completely, or in fact, continued to increase for a period and are now in reverse. The company says RRP revenue growth is expected to accelerate in H2, driven by the timing of new and enhanced product launches, leading to FY growth around the middle of their 30‐50% guidance range. This is below our full year estimate where we are looking for growth of 79%.

Excel Developer @SupposeToBeWorking... : I'm sorry, starting providing proof for your bold assertions.

JP11:29am

Ah there we go. Working from home not all it is cracked up to be...

JP11:29am

Downgrade to Sell post strong FY19 results European online classified stocks are in vogue, with private equity interest coupled with a rally in quality, driving multiples to new heights. With Auto Trader now trading at 26x FY20E EPS, our valuation models imply this is pricing-in a 10% FY19-26 revenue CAGR. In contrast Auto Trader has delivered revenue growth of +6% in FY18 and +8% in FY19 and our updated forecast for FY20E is +6%. An acceleration requires Auto Trader to both capture c£130 of classified revenue for every used car sold (vs c£90 in FY19), and also to capture almost all (c75%) of the £250m of new revenue opportunities previously identified in a prior note. While this may be feasible, we think the risk/reward is skewed negatively with limited potential upside, and continued risk of a no-deal Brexit. Sell.

SupposeToBeWorking... @Excel Sure, not loads. But this is only really about the 160'000 tory party members. What matters is how many of them are retired vs working. Fullfact seems to think average age ~57, so maybe less than I first would have guessed.
Excel Developer whilst average age of Labour is 53.
11:29 am
JP11:30am

Trading positive – but risks existAuto Trader is trading strongly as evidenced by last week’s results (ARPR +9%), and guidance for “another year of strong ARPR growth”. However, the results showed Auto Trader’s model is not without risk. 1) Weak guidance on Manufacturing & Agency revenues mean we cut FY20-21E EPS by 2-3%; 2) Auto Trader guided for negative stock impact on ARPR with transaction volumes continuing to be weak (advert page views were down -6.5% for H219 yoy); 3) Used car inventory is concentrating among large dealers, which impacted FY19 ARPR by c-130bps. For the top 15 dealers we track, used cars on their own websites is up 8% in May-19 yoy vs 3% for Auto Trader; 4) Key products (e.g., Premium, Dealer Finance, Retail Checker, Vehicle Checker) are near maturity. We question whether Auto Trader investments (FY19 opex +3%) are sufficient to deliver the next generation of products at the speed the market requires.

JP11:30am

Where could we be wrong?Given private equity interest in this sector, we have built an LBO model to assess a key risk to our thesis. Our base case forecasts suggest a 9% IRR assuming 1) a 20% entry premium; 2) current 21x EV/EBITDA could be achieved at exit, 3) 5x leverage; 4) 4% cost of debt. Sensitivities to these assumptions are provided on page 11 of the note.Valuation: 540p DCF based price target (prev. 530p)We assume core marketing business rev grows at a 6% FY19-26 cagr and continue to see £125m incremental rev from transactions (50% of the opportunity) longer term.

cracklenpop I'm watching the Johnson presser on mute as you can't believe a word he says.

Purplebricks is small in the scheme of things, but they are now a substantial owner. Might elicit a takeover at some stage. But Purplebricks is a different RE vertical to immowelt.

AC Thanks for letting me know :)
A. M. (morning all)
11:39 am
JP11:39am

Market is a bit meh, but as its a hot growth stock we should probably post some of the grey in my inbox.

JP11:39am

Guidance remains unchanged. Here's Peel Hunt:

cracklenpop @JP R u feeling vindicated re. BYND after the 25% drop yesterday? https://www.ft.com/content/cbe9f774-8c4d-11e9-a24d-b42f641eca37
1966AndAllThat Does BCA still own their plots? At one time they were more of a property punt with a bit of car selling on top to cover the interest payments. Bit like urban garden centres, car park and self storage companies.
JP11:40am

Relevance wins. Despite the weak High Street and industry data, boohoo has enjoyed one if its strongest weeks outside of peak in May, as the group’s brands continue to resonate strongly with customers across all markets. Group revenue growth of 39% for Q1 came ahead of consensus (+35%) but behind our top-of-the range 43.8%. Group gross margin was down 20bps in the quarter, in line with our expectations. Combined group performance put boohoo at the top of the UK Hitwise rankings in May, for the first time. By territory, the group continues to make strong progress across all markets, with UK +27%, Europe +72% and the US +64%. boohoo brand momentum continues. boohoo brands continued the strong momentum shown in P4 (Jan/Feb 2019), with sales up 27% to £123.5m, coming in ahead of consensus (18%) and PHe (25%). Strong gross margin performance, +210bps illustrates the strength of the offer.

11:40 am
JP11:40am

Nasty Gal starting to resonate in the UK. Nasty Gal also performed strongly, with the brand is running ahead of PLT at the same stage in its lifecycle. Sales increased by 153% to £18.2m, ahead of PHe (+132%) and consensus (74%). Medium term growth assumptions for Nasty Gal are relatively modest (50%-60% for the next two years) against the aggressive historical growth profiles of boohoo and PLT, suggesting medium term upside if Nasty Gal can develop into a similar scale business as the lead two brands. PLT sales +42%, but below consensus. The gap to our numbers was on PLT, with sales up 42% – consensus was looking for 53% growth, PHe assumptions were set at 60%. Coming up against c+160% comparatives, we are very relaxed on performance, as PLT continues to deliver strong growth and customer KPIs. Both the market and our growth profile assumes a slowing growth rate over 2019/20. PLT margins were also down 280bps over Q1, coming up against tough comparatives. Looking ahead, PLT comparatives fall sharply in Q2 against last year’s warehouse move, suggesting the growth rate should pick up.

JP11:40am

Forecasts unchanged, reiterate Buy. The Buy case for boohoo is built on the foundation of global relevance and significant medium term potential across all markets, rather than quarterly targets. The resurgence of boohoo brand and the development of Nasty Gal both score highly on this front. PLT’s growth rate against tough comparatives remains impressive, albeit below market expectations this quarter. Overall, this another strong performance against a weakened High Street backdrop. Trades on 42x PER, 21x EV/EBITDA, 2x sales the shares trade on a deserved premium to peers

JP11:41am

11:42 am
JP11:42am

Pure-play fast fashion group boohoo has delivered a strong trading update for the three months to 31st May 2019 which saw group revenue growth of 39% year-on-year (yoy), slightly ahead of the Q1 consensus revenue growth of 35%. The growth was across all three brands and all geographies with UK revenues up 27% and international revenues up 56%. Gross margins declined 20 basis points to 55.0%, as the group continued to invest in developing the newer brands in the portfolio.

Across the three brands revenue growth was robust. Boohoo brand continued their momentum from Q4, posting revenues of £124m, up 28% at constant currency and gross margins up 210 basis points. Pretty Little Thing (PLT) posted revenues of £112m during Q1 with growth of 42% yoy (at constant currency) and margin investment of 280 basis points. Nasty Gal posted revenues of £18m, growth of 157% (at constant currency) during Q1 and 280 basis point investment in gross margin.

JP11:43am

In terms of outlook there is no change to FY guidance for sales growth of between 25-30% per annum with an adjusted EBITDA margin of around 10% but the tone of the comment from the company is both positive and highlights the global opportunity, as it continues to scale its multi-brand platform.

The newish CEO John Lyttle commented: “The Group has made a strong start to the year as we continue to disrupt and capture market share in the UK and internationally across all our brands. I'm delighted that the Group topped the UK Hitwise rankings in May for the first time, demonstrating how our multi-brand strategy is really capturing our customers' attention. We have ambitious plans for the Group, and continue to invest to ensure that our scalable multi-brand platform is well-positioned to disrupt, gain market share and capitalise on the global opportunity in front of us.”

In terms of valuation boohoo trades on a one year (year to February 2020) forward PE multiple of 43x and an EV/EBITDA multiple of 22x. In our recent note (20th May – Good growth potential but fairly valued for now) we provided some valuation analysis where we used a number of metrics (EV/sales, EV/EBITDA and PE valuations) to drive out a fair value. In our analysis we derived a fair value of £2.47 per share, believing that the shares are up with events for now. We reiterate our HOLD rating.

chad_john Bojo saying the FT is his preferred paper... nice plug.

11:44 am
JP11:44am

Boohoo has reported impressive Q1 growth with strong gains across all regions. We believe the business is strategically well positioned for long term expansion and that current run-rate growth is undervalued. Strong Q1 performance. boohoo continues to deliver exceptional growth with revenue +39% to £254m. A 27% uptick in UK revenue -the most mature region, representing 57% of revenue in 2019A –strikes us as particularly impressive given the challenging UK consumer environment. Gross margin maintained at c55%. No change to forecasts. The business looks to be running ahead of our estimates (2020E FY revenue growth +31%) however we consider it too early to push through upgrades. Management guidance also remains unchanged.

JP11:45am

Powerful platform for expansion. boohoo is delivering impressive growth across all brands (boohoo +27%, PrettyLittleThing +42%, Nasty Gal +153%) and all regions (UK +27%, EU +72%, US +64%, RoW +26%). We believe this demonstrates the effectiveness of the model with its fast fashion, value-led offering winning market share. High stock turn and limited software development spend results in substantial cash generation (net cash increased to £194m), providing the resources to self-fund further expansion. Reiterate BUY recommendation. With a multi-brand, international strategy we believe boohoo is well positioned for long term expansion and that the current run-rate of growth is being fundamentally undervalued. Benchmarking against Inditex we see upside of over 30% to the current share price.
